source: Banking Law
text: A Garnishee Order is an order issued by a court to attach funds belonging to a judgment debtor that are held with a bank or a third party. It prevents the bank from releasing money from the debtorâ€™s account until the court gives further instruction. The purpose of the Garnishee Order is to ensure that the creditor can recover the amount owed by legally freezing the debtorâ€™s funds.

source: Banking Law
text: Under a Garnishee Order, the bank is required to disclose whether the customer (the debtor) has sufficient funds and must hold those funds without allowing withdrawals. If funds are available, the court may direct the bank to transfer the required amount to the creditor. Failure of the bank to comply may lead to legal liability. This order applies only to the balance available at the time of service.

source: Banking Law
text: The Garnishee Order grants the creditor the right to access the debtor's funds held by a bank through court intervention. It restricts the debtor from withdrawing money and requires the bank to hold or pay the specified amount to the creditor once ordered. This ensures legal recovery of dues even if the debtor attempts to avoid payment.

source: Agatha Christie Biography.pdf
text: BIOGRAPHY OF AGATHA CHRISTIE Agatha Christie was a mystery writer who was one of the world's top-selling authors with works like 'Murder on the Orient Express' and 'The Mystery of the Blue Train.' Who Was Agatha Christie? Best-selling author Agatha Christie published her first novel, The Mysterious Affair at Styles, in 1920, and went on to become one of the most famous writers in history, with mysteries like Murder at the Vicarage, Partners in Crime and Sad Cypress. She sold billions of copies o

source: Agatha Christie Biography.pdf
text: f her work and was also a noted playwright and romance author. Early Life and Background Christie was born Agatha Mary Clarissa Miller on September 15, 1890, in Torquay, Devon, in the southwest part of England. The youngest of three siblings, she was educated at home by her mother, who encouraged her daughter to write. As a child, Christie enjoyed fantasy play and creating characters, and, when she was 16, she moved to Paris for a time to study vocals and piano. In 1914, she wed Colonel Archibal

source: Agatha Christie Biography.pdf
text: d Christie, a Royal Flying Corps pilot, and took up nursing during World War I. She published her first book, The Mysterious Affair at Styles, in 1920; the story focused on the murder of a rich heiress and introduced readers to one of Christie's most famous characters Belgian detective Hercule Poirot. Books and Disappearance In 1926, Christie released The Murder of Roger Ackroyd, a hit which was later marked as a genre classic and one of the author's all-time favorites. She dealt with tumult tha

source: Agatha Christie Biography.pdf
text: t same year, however, as her mother died and her husband revealed that he was in a relationship with another woman. Traumatized by the revelation, Christie disappeared only to be discovered by authorities several days later at a Harrogate hotel, registered under the name of her husband's mistress. Christie would recover, with her and Archibald divorcing in 1928. In 1930, she married archaeology professor Max Mallowan, with whom she traveled on several expeditions, later recounting her trips in t

source: Agatha Christie Biography.pdf
text: he 1946 memoir Come, Tell Me How You Live. The year of her new nuptials also saw the release of Murder at the Vicarage, which became another classic and introduced readers to Miss Jane Marple, an enquiring village lady. Cast of Characters Poirot and Marple are Christie's most well-known detectives, with the two featured in dozens of novels and short stories. Poirot made the most appearances in Christie's work in titles that included Ackroyd, The Mystery of the Blue Train (1928) and Death in the

source: Agatha Christie Biography.pdf
text: Clouds (1935). Miss Marple has been featured in books like The Moving Finger (1942) and A Pocket Full of

source: Agatha Christie Biography.pdf
text: Rye (1953), and been played on screen by actresses like Angela Lansbury, Helen Hayes and Geraldine McEwan. Other notable Christie characters include Tuppence and Tommy Beresford, Colonel Race, Parker Pyne and Ariadne Oliver. Sold More Than Two Billion Copies Writing well into her later years, Christie wrote more than 70 detective novels as well as short fiction. Though she also wrote romance novels like Unfinished Portrait (1934) and A Daughter's a Daughter (1952) under the name Mary Westmacott,

source: Agatha Christie Biography.pdf
text: Christie's success as an author of sleuth stories has earned her titles like the "Queen of Crime" and the "Queen of Mystery." Christie can also be considered a queen of all publishing genres as she is one of the top-selling authors in history, with her combined works selling more than 2 billion copies worldwide. Christie was a renowned playwright as well, with works like The Hollow (1951) and Verdict (1958). Her play The Mousetrap opened in 1952 at the Ambassador Theatre and at more than 8,800

source: Agatha Christie Biography.pdf
text: showings during 21 years holds the record for the longest unbroken run in a London theater. Additionally, several of Christie's works have become popular movies, including Murder on the Orient Express (1974) and Death on the Nile (1978). Christie was made a dame in 1971. In 1974, she made her last public appearance for the opening night of the play version of Murder on the Orient Express. Christie died on January 12, 1976.

source: web
text:
Elon Reeve Musk, born on June 28, 1971, in Pretoria, South Africa, is a South African-born American entrepreneur, businessman, and engineer known for his leadership roles in several high-profile technology companies.2He holds citizenship in South Africa, Canada, and the United States, having obtained Canadian citizenship through his mother and later becoming a U.S. citizen in 2002.2
9Musk emigrated to Canada in 1988 to avoid mandatory military service under South Africa’s apartheid regime and later moved to the United States to pursue business ventures.9
10He earned bachelor's degrees in physics and economics from the University of Pennsylvania in 1997.2Musk co-founded Zip2, an online city guide software company, which was sold to Compaq in 1999 for $307 million.7
8He then co-founded X.com, an online payment company that merged with Confinity to become PayPal, which was acquired by eBay in 2002.2
7The proceeds from PayPal enabled him to fund his next ventures.In 2002, Musk founded SpaceX, a space technology company focused on reducing space transportation costs and enabling the colonization of Mars; he serves as its CEO and chief engineer.2
8In 2004, he joined Tesla, Inc. (originally Tesla Motors), an electric vehicle and clean energy company, as chairman and product architect, becoming CEO in 2008.8
9Under his leadership, Tesla developed the Roadster, Model S, Model X, and Model 3, and expanded into solar energy products and battery storage.3
8Musk is also the founder and CEO of The Boring Company, which aims to reduce urban traffic through underground tunnel networks.8
9He co-founded Neuralink in 2016 to develop brain-machine interface technology.8
9In 2015, he co-founded OpenAI, a nonprofit artificial intelligence research organization, to promote safe and beneficial AI.8
9In 2022, he acquired Twitter, a major social media platform, and rebranded it as X in July 2023.2
6Musk has been the wealthiest person in the world since 2021, with an estimated net worth of around $500 billion as of October 2025 according to Forbes.2
6He was named Time Person of the Year in 2021.2In 2025, he served as the Commissioner of the Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE) during the second administration of U.S. President Donald Trump, stepping down in May 2025.6
9Musk has been married twice—first to Justine Wilson (2000–2008) and then to Talulah Riley (2010–2012, 2013–2016)—and had a domestic partnership with musician Grimes from 2018 to 2021.2
4He is the father of at least 14 children.2
4He is also known for his public statements on technology, artificial intelligence, space exploration, and politics, which have drawn both acclaim and controversy.

text:
Embeddings in machine learning are numerical representations of complex, high-dimensional data—such as words, images, or user interactions—mapped into a lower-dimensional vector space where meaningful patterns and relationships are preserved.1This process transforms raw data into dense, continuous vectors that capture semantic, syntactic, or contextual relationships, enabling machine learning models to process and reason about real-world data more effectively.3
5Unlike manual methods like one-hot encoding, embeddings are learned automatically from data through algorithms such as neural networks, allowing models to identify intricate patterns that may be difficult for humans to define explicitly.1
10These vector representations are typically low-dimensional but retain essential information, making them computationally efficient and suitable for tasks like natural language processing, computer vision, and recommendation systems.2
11In an embedding space, similar items are positioned closer together, with distances between vectors reflecting their relative similarity—measured using metrics like cosine or Euclidean distance.5
6For example, in word embeddings, semantically related words like "dad" and "father" appear near each other, while "play" in "I went to a play" and "I like to play" can be distinguished through contextual embeddings.5
4Embeddings are created using various models, including Word2Vec, BERT, and SVD, which are trained to generate meaningful vector representations from large datasets.4
5They are widely used to reduce dimensionality, improve model generalization, and enable innovative applications such as AI chatbots, image recognition, and personalized recommendations.4
5Embedding models can be deployed via platforms like AWS, where services such as Titan Embeddings and Amazon SageMaker support the creation and use of embeddings for real-world AI applications.4

text: Narendra Modi is the 18th Prime Minister of India, serving since 2024 under his third term as part of the 3rd Modi Ministry.2Born on 17 September 1950 in Vadnagar, Gujarat, he is a member of the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) and the Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh (RSS), a right-wing Hindutva paramilitary volunteer organisation.2He previously served as the Chief Minister of Gujarat from 2001 to 2014 and is the Member of Parliament (MP) for Varanasi, Uttar Pradesh.2Modi has been a central figure in Indian politics, leading the BJP to significant electoral victories in 2014 and 2019, and his administration has been marked by major policy initiatives such as demonetisation, the Goods and Services Tax, the revocation of Jammu and Kashmir's special status, and the Citizenship Amendment Act, alongside controversial events like the 2020 Delhi riots and the 2025 India–Pakistan conflict.2

text:
Quantum mechanics is the fundamental physical theory that describes the behavior of matter and light at atomic and subatomic scalesthe fundamental physical theory that describes the behavior of matter and light at atomic and subatomic scales, where classical physics fails to provide accurate predictions.2It explains phenomena such as wave-particle duality, where particles like electrons and photons exhibit both wave-like and particle-like properties depending on the experimental setup.5
10A key feature is superposition, where a quantum system can exist in multiple states simultaneously until measured, at which point the wave function collapses to a definite state.9
10The theory also predicts quantum entanglement, where particles become correlated in such a way that the state of one instantly influences the other, regardless of distance, and quantum tunneling, where particles can pass through energy barriers they classically shouldn't be able to.10Despite its success in making highly precise predictions—such as in quantum electrodynamics, which matches experimental results to within one part in ten billion2—the interpretation of what quantum mechanics reveals about the nature of reality remains a subject of debate among physicists and philosophers.8
12

text:
The title "I Really Do" refers to both a 2025 Punjabi song by Karan Aujla and a 2024 romance novel by Emily K. Hardy.The song "I Really Do" is a Punjabi track released in 2025 as part of the album P-Pop CulturePunjabi track released in 2025 as part of the album P-Pop Culture.2It is sung, written, and composed by Karan Aujla, with music by Ikky.2
3The lyrics express deep emotional conflict, portraying a man who is deeply in love but feels trapped, unable to stay with the person he loves or leave them.2The song features a music video starring Karan Aujla and actress Aaveera Singh Masson.2It has a duration of 3 minutes and 13 seconds.4The song is available for streaming and download on platforms like JioSaavn 4and is also featured on LyricsDecoder and LyricsMint with full lyrics and translations.2
3The novel I Really Do by Emily K. Hardy is a lesbian romance published in 2024.6It follows Brooke Kent, who hasn't spoken to her family in thirteen years until her younger brother invites her to his wedding.6
7He asks her to bring a partner, any woman, to the event. With no romantic partner, Brooke's friends suggest she invite Anna Fourchette, the woman she has been pining for.6
7Anna agrees, and the story unfolds as Brooke navigates a week in London with her estranged family while pretending to be in a relationship with Anna, all while risking genuine feelings.6
7The book is categorized under lesbian romance, fake dating, and contemporary fiction.6

text:
Machine learning is a subset of artificial intelligence focused on enabling algorithms to learn patterns from data and make predictions or decisions without explicit programming for each taska subset of artificial intelligence focused on enabling algorithms to learn patterns from data and make predictions or decisions without explicit programming for each task.3
11It works by training models on datasets, where the model learns to map inputs to outputs through iterative processes, improving its performance over time as it encounters new data.2
5The central goal is generalization—applying knowledge gained from training data to accurately predict outcomes on new, unseen data.3Machine learning encompasses various approaches, including supervised learning (using labeled data for classification or regression), unsupervised learning (finding hidden structures in unlabeled data), and reinforcement learning (learning optimal actions through interaction with an environment).2

text:
Earphones are small loudspeaker devices worn over or inserted into the ear to convert electrical signals into sound waves for private listeningsmall loudspeaker devices worn over or inserted into the ear to convert electrical signals into sound waves for private listening.3They are often used interchangeably with the term "earbuds," though there is a distinction: earbuds rest in the outer ear without entering the ear canal, while earphones, also known as in-ear headphones or in-ear monitors, are designed to fit snugly inside the ear canal.11This in-ear design provides a more direct connection to the sound source and can offer better sound isolation from ambient noise.12Earphones are typically lightweight and portable, making them ideal for use with mobile devices like smartphones, MP3 players, and during physical activities such as running or working out.8
12They are commonly powered by portable audio devices and are available in a wide range of prices and audio quality levels, from low-cost models to high-fidelity options.9The term "earphone" can also refer to the component of a telephone receiver or other communication devices that is held to the ear or inserted into the ear.6
